content: The "Veterans' Benefits Improvement Act of 2007" allows disabled members of the armed forces residing temporarily in housing owned by a family member to receive specially adaptive housing assistance. Section 2102A of title 38, United States Code, is amended to allow the Secretary to provide assistance to active duty members of the Armed Forces suffering from disabilities incurred in line of duty. Establishment of the Visual Impairment and Orientation and Mobility Professionals Scholarship Program under Chapter 76 of title 38, United States Code. The Department of Veterans Affairs Visual Impairment and Orientation and Mobility Professionals Scholarship Program, established under Chapter 76 of title 38, aims to increase the supply of qualified blind rehabilitation specialists for the Department and the Nation. Eligibility requires enrollment as a full-time or part-time student in specified fields of education or training. The Department of Veterans Affairs Visual Impairment and Orientation and Mobility Professionals Scholarship Program aims to increase the supply of qualified blind rehabilitation specialists. Eligibility requires enrollment in education or training leading to a degree or certificate in visual impairment or orientation and mobility, or both, and appointment or retention in a specific position. An agreement between the Secretary and a participant includes providing a scholarship for a specified number of school years for pursuing the required education or training. The participant's agreement includes serving as a full-time employee in the Veterans Health Administration for three years after completing education or training, and serving in a Department facility selected by the Secretary. An extension may result in a scholarship provided for the additional school years granted. The participant's agreement includes serving as a full-time employee in the Veterans Health Administration for three years after completing education or training, and serving in a Department facility selected by the Secretary. An extension may result in a scholarship provided for the additional school years granted. The scholarship covers tuition and other educational expenses for the participant. The scholarship amount for full-time students in the Program is capped at $15,000 per year, while part-time students receive a prorated amount. The scholarship can be paid for a maximum of six school years. Participants must serve as full-time employees in the Veterans Health Administration for three years after completing their education or training. Participants in the Program can receive a scholarship for up to three years of full-time coursework. The Secretary can arrange for educational expenses to be paid directly to the institution. Full-time coursework requirements are 30 semester hours for undergraduates and 18 semester hours for graduates per school year. Participants must fulfill a three-year obligated service in the Veterans Health Administration after completing their education or training. Participants in the Program must serve as full-time employees of the Department in clinical practice or other healthcare positions determined by the Secretary. The service commencement date is notified 60 days in advance, marking the start of the obligated service period. If not employed full-time in the Veterans Health Administration, the Secretary will appoint the participant after the service commencement date. Participants in the Program must serve as full-time employees in healthcare positions determined by the Secretary. The service commencement date is 60 days in advance, and for those not in the Veterans Health Administration, the Secretary will appoint or assign them accordingly based on their education or training. Service commencement dates vary based on the type of degree received. The service commencement date for participants in the Program is determined based on their course completion date or licensure as a registered nurse. For part-time students, the Secretary will prescribe the service commencement date through regulations. Participants are considered to have begun their obligated service period, except as provided in paragraph (2). Participants in the Program begin their obligated service period either on the date they become full-time employees in the Veterans Health Administration after course completion or when they are assigned to a position related to their training. If a participant is already a full-time employee in the Veterans Health Administration in a relevant capacity on the course completion date, they are considered to have started their obligated service then. Participants in the Program start their obligated service period upon completing their education or training. If they fail to meet the agreement requirements, they must repay the unearned portion of the educational assistance received, as determined by the Secretary's regulations. The Secretary may waive or suspend obligations for service or payment under the program in cases of noncompliance due to circumstances beyond the individual's control. Any repayment obligation to the Secretary is considered a debt owed to the United States, which is not discharged in bankruptcy if less than five years have passed since the agreement termination. "Subchapter VIII - Visual Impairment and Orientation and Mobility Professionals Scholarship Program" The text discusses the Visual Impairment and Orientation and Mobility Professionals Scholarship Program, outlining eligibility, scholarship details, obligated service, and repayment for failure to meet requirements. Amendments are made to include the program in the existing chapter. Amendments are made to include the Visual Impairment and Orientation and Mobility Professionals Scholarship Program in chapter 76 of title 38, United States. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs shall implement subchapter VIII. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs must implement subchapter VIII of chapter 76 of title 38, United States Code within six months of the enactment of this Act. SEC. 4. VETERANS' REEMPLOYMENT RIGHTS REPORT IMPROVEMENT. Section 4332 of title 38, United States Code is amended to include additional report requirements related to cases reviewed by the Secretary of Defense under the National Committee for Employer Support of the Guard and Reserve of the Department of Defense during the fiscal year. The Secretary of Defense will coordinate with other agencies to categorize and provide information on disability-related cases reported under new report requirements. Effective date for these amendments is specified. The amendments made by this section will apply to reports submitted after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 5. INCREASE IN NUMBER OF MEMBERS OF ADVISORY COMMITTEE ON VETERANS EMPLOYMENT, TRAINING, AND EMPLOYER OUTREACH. Section 4110(c)(1) of title 38, United States Code, is amended by striking "15" and inserting "16".
